description.narrative: Support to a coalition of Indonesian human rights civil society organisations aiming at strengthening the ASEAN human rights mechanism throught a proactive and constructive dialogue between the civil society and ASEAN member states and ASEAN institutions, e.g. AICHR.

Support to a coalition of Indonesian human rights civil society organisations aiming at strengthening the ASEAN human rights mechanism throught a proactive and constructive dialogue between the civil society and ASEAN member states and ASEAN institutions, e.g. AICHR.

The project entitled “Promoting Fundamental Freedoms by Ensuring an Effective, Accessible and Responsive ASEAN Human Rights System” was designed to be a three-year project from 2011 to 2013. It was expected that by end of the project, ASEAN and its human rights mechanisms would be more accessible, responsive and effective. There were three results to be achieved by implementing the project. They were: 1) ASEAN’s procedures, mechanisms and standards to protect human rights are in line with /promote the international human rights principles and values. 2) A Strategic working relationship between civil society and ASEAN Human Rights Mechanisms that encourage dialogue and engagement. 3) Documentation and preservation of lessons learnt to be shared among civil society in engaging ASEAN human rights systems.

description.narrative:
The Embassy ended the support with HRWG in 2012, with examples of the results as followed:
Result area 1: - Positive feedback from ACWC on the HRWG’s submission based on its research on constitutionalism. - ACWC used the inputs in their meeting with AICHR to discuss the draft of ASEAN Human Rights Declaration. - The inclusion of HRWG’s inputs on freedom of religion, economic, cultural and social rights in ASEAN Human Rights Declaration. - The discourse of human rights principles and values and democratic participation of decision making have appeared in press statements of ACWC, AICHR, ACMW, ASEAN Secretary General and County Permanent Representative (CPR). The adoption of HRWG’s inputs to the EU’s statement and US Secretary State’s statement to respond ASEAN Human Rights Declaration.
Result area 2: - Informal Dialogue with ASEAN Secretary General (ASG) on Human Rights has generated further innovative ideas in building democratic engagement between ASEAN officials and the civil society. - It also generated the idea to make the discussion on emerging human rights issues in ASEAN by bringing respected speakers from the region. - Informal Dialogue with ASG on Human Rights has also emerged as a new normative ground in ASEAN where the series of dialogues have shown the eagerness of the representatives of member states, such as the Country Permanent Representative (CPR), to engage with civil society groups so as to give substance to the claims of a people-oriented ASEAN. - Commitment from ASEAN CPR to continue the dialogue in the future in more systematic and substantive discussion. - The practice of dialogue and consultation with civil society within ASEAN through meetings or the inclusion of civil society’s statements are gradually established.
Result area 3: - The role of civil society in building ASEAN Community is more visible than before as it is reflected in a number of statements of the ASEAN officials. - The documentation of reviewing the ASEAN Charter in 2013 from civil society’s observation and experience that can be further researched in 2012. - More and more civil societies gained knowledge and experiences in engaging with ASEAN, its limitations, structures and its ways of working. - Through their engagement, ASEAN Officials understand the dynamism of civil society in the region. Renewal Commitment from civil society and think tank to engage with official process in ASEAN.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
